urn:contentItem:5WNV-1FV1-F0J6-J3KV-00000-00LETTERS2019-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 16LETTERS

Why no outcry?

Senator Nick McKim's treatment during his recent visit to Manus Island points out clearly what we already know; that the treatment of detainees there is too bad to be made public and is embarrassing to PNG, while our government thinks it can get away with "deterrent" abuse because the camps are far away over the horizon where we might with luck forget about them.

But the past three weeks have made clear what some of us may not have known, that systematic mistreatment exists in detention centres here in our own capital cities.

As you have reported, at Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation two children who were healthy on being detained were recently found to be seriously vitamin deficient, one with teeth so rotten she needed dental surgery at the age of two. In the past three weeks in MITA two small children have required hospital attention, one with an entirely preventable head injury, the other with flu. In both cases it's claimed the parents had to call outside advocates to ring an ambulance because management had refused. An adult who had been complaining of chest pain fell dead. Another man was desperate enough to try to set himself on fire. Another is so ill he has sewn his lips together.

All this in Broadmeadows. In an Australian government facility. In our midst. Why is there not an outcry? Why do we not treat people seeking asylum like people?

Janet Gaden, Daylesford

Presenting an ugly image

The continuing detention of asylum seekers on Manus Island and Nauru is inhumane and has been condemned by the United Nations. It also presents a very ugly image of Australia to the rest of the world.

We who have been blessed by being born into a life of freedom and plenty are inflicting a slow living death on less fortunate human beings whose bravery and resourcefulness could have been an asset to our country. It is beyond time to end their suffering.

Fiona Moore, Ivanhoe

Restore the cuts

It is good to see that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission recognises the huge benefit an independent ABC and SBS can provide to the community. Let's hope the government takes note and restores some of the recent funding cuts to the ABC.

Margaret Hanrahan, Thornbury

A self-defeating move

The Reserve Bank, Treasury and our Treasurer never seem to be able to read the future outcome of their financial management decisions nor do they seem to be able to see even the immediate outcomes.

One does not need any special knowledge to know from experience that by reducing the official interest rate, the value of the dollar would fall against other currencies. Again this has happened - to immediately defeat the government's predicted spending spree that is supposed to stimulate a dreary economy.

Practically all the goods we buy on the domestic market these days are made overseas and will come with a hike in prices to compensate for our lower dollar. So those who have only a modest income - which is the majority, will hang on to the old and forgo buying new until absolutely necessary. So sorry, Prime Minister and Treasurer, but we will not be buying to stimulate the economy.

Especially stringent at this time are we retirees (in my case self-funded) who have lost our spending money on account of interest on term deposits no longer even keeping up with the inflation rate.

With an unpredictable future (re. health and housing) we dare not diminish our capital, which would diminish our security.

Graham Page, Buxton

Not holding my breath

Good to see our Treasurer taking on digital giants Facebook and Google, although to describe the ACCC report into digital platforms as "ground breaking" and "truly a world first" is classic Frydenberg hyperbole.

The reality is there has been a global backlash against "big tech" for some time, especially in the US, where the Department of Justice has launched an investigation into internet platforms and where there are calls for the major players to be broken up on competition grounds.

Perhaps Josh Frydenberg might also look at formulating regulations requiring Facebook to extirpate "fake news" to ensure the integrity of our elections, although I do recall a press release emanating from Frydenberg's office suggesting Labor was proposing a "death tax", so we won't hold our breath on this one.

Neil Hudson, East Melbourne

They are linked

Former Beyond Blue chairman and founder Jeff Kennett, appears to have forgotten the charter of that organisation.

He claims that mental health is no excuse for poor behaviour, but one would have thought that violent behaviour was entirely caused by a mental disturbance.

A man desperately wanting access to his medicine might well be excused for a bad moment, especially since he has apologised and will pay for the damage.

Mr Kennett, who created a pall of gloom over Victoria for seven years, should quietly disappear into his retirement.

Graeme Lee, Fitzroy

It's worth the cost

Ursula Miller, health insurance may be costly and yes, there is a "gap" to be paid (Letters, 27/7).

But I have private health insurance so that I don't have to wait a painful/nervous 18 months to have a semi-urgent procedure that my private health insurance membership means I will have done within five days.

Simple.

Jen Gladstones, Heidelberg

Right idea, wrong target

Dick Smith received $500,000 in excess franking credits, which means he received at a minimum $1.6 million in share dividends. The payment is tax free and is paid from other people's taxes. His payment represents $19,230 a fortnight - 33 times more than a person on Newstart - $575 per fortnight.

The Prime Minister rightfully claims "we are not an open cheque book" and can't increase Newstart. But governments make choices. Labor promised to stop the Dick Smiths of the world getting this largesse. Our PM chooses to keep paying him. In my humble opinion, the PM simply chooses to pay cheques to the wrong people.

John Rome, Mount Lawley, WA

A little perspective please

Is Peter Hartcher ("Setka a tricky problem to solve", The Age, 27/7) being deliberately provocative or does his attack on the union movement truly represent his own beliefs, strongly reflecting those of the LNP? At the least, his is an extremely narrowly focused attack. No doubt the CFMMEU have gone beyond the pale in a range of areas as have some other unions, but this is surely inevitable in the highly charged negotiations between union leadership and large corporations.

But their behaviour pales into insignificance in comparison with the long-term behaviour of the large financial institutions, the technology companies, mining companies - with the damage done to the environment, and, finally, the widespread underpayment of staff in the hospitality industry. All of this has been fully documented.

Without unions, workers would have severely diminished rights, especially now that the political right is in such ascendancy. The present stagnant state of wage growth will be exacerbated without unions, and this will have a strongly negative affect on the overall economy, not to mention the diminution of other rights for those who do not own capital.

Greg Bailey, St Andrews

Selective concern

In recent articles there has understandably been significant outrage about the stockpiles of waste resulting from the lack of recycling and single-use plastic bags. Single-use nappies significantly contribute to this waste problem, making up 4 per cent of landfill, but their environmental impact is conveniently ignored, even by the Greens.

It is estimated 95 per cent of Australian families use disposable nappies instead of cloth (reusable) nappies, yet the reasons to avoid disposable nappies are compelling: australianscience.com.au says Australians use 5.6 million disposable nappies a day, meaning more than 2 billion nappies go into landfill around Australia each year. These can take up to 500 years to decompose. They report that disposable nappies use three times more energy, 20 times more raw materials and twice the water than reusable nappies during manufacture.

It is estimated that using disposable nappies costs $3250 per child and Sustainability Victoria says it takes one cup of crude oil to make each disposable nappy. Vanuatu is banning disposable nappies later this year but, surprisingly, the Greens have no policy and are not interested in raising this environmental time bomb.

Does our concern for the environment cease when the more environmentally-friendly choice involves the washing of smelly and dirty reusable nappies?

Reusable nappies will save several thousands of dollars per child and are better for the environment, so why wouldn't families choose them?

A win for families and a win for the environment.

David Charles, Newtown

Follow BHP's lead

Wow: We have BHP, one of our largest businesses, leading action on climate change. Some short-term pain, huge long-term gain. Bringing shareholders along with them by commonsense explanation and concrete plans and action.

Scott Morrison, now is your chance for real action, not hollow rhetoric. Your citizens are the shareholders of the nation and the planet. You are our leader. Lead us into a sustainable future.

How good is BHP chief executive officer Andrew McKenzie? Let us see how good our Prime Minister is.

David Court, Glen iris

We owe it to our pets

Jason Steger's description of the passing of his beloved dog Pluto ("Our pets deserve love until the end", Comment, 24/7) was so sad. I have had the difficult experience of having to say goodbye to three dogs and two cats over many years. I stayed with them and held them as soon as the injection quickly took effect.

I do not understand how someone could just leave their loving pet to die alone. I feel that it was my thank you to these faithful pets and I feel better for being with them at this sad time.

Elaine Cullinane, Hampton

urn:contentItem:5T45-DSN1-JCJY-G2JX-00000-00Letters: believe in change - for the better;We must exploit the power of positive thinking if we are to curb the effects of dangerous movements in our climate2018-08-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisOPINIONVersion:1Letters: believe in change - for the betterWe must exploit the power of positive thinking if we are to curb the effects of dangerous movements in our climate

In 1982, when I was having a bit of an existential crisis while campaigning for nuclear disarmament and heavily pregnant, my father-in-law related the story of a neighbour who'd shot dead his wife, children and himself during the Cuba crisis because he couldn't face the prospect of inevitable nuclear war. "He could have been enjoying his grandchildren now."

Climate change ( It's the end of the Earth as we know it, Comment) appears to momentous, and not withstanding the depressing (and logical) thoughts that it's too late, too complex, too difficult and so forth, I still reckon it's a good strategy to act as if changes in human behaviour, individual and collective, on any scale - massive and radical would be good options - might make a difference. A growing body of scientific researchers, journalists, activists, politicians, ethical lifestylers and eco-warriors keeps going "despite".

My personal perspective is that there's not a lot of positive gain in saying it's a pointless endeavour. The physicist Niels Bohr said something along the lines that predicition is difficult, especially when it's about the future. If we give up in despair now, we may not be in a position to "enjoy our grandchildren". I would guess that multiple catastrophes are inevitable; it's a question of what kind of catastrophes are we facing, can we mitigate/prevent any of them, and what would we like to make happen instead? Perhaps over the next few centuries, Anthropocene doesn't have to have its current negative connotation if we commit to improving our meaning-making, attitudes and choices about stewardship of "our" planet. Online Contribution (Somerset Jen)

We have all moved on from Richard Dawkins's fundamentalism, aeons ago ( "Intelligent design? How come He made so many blunders?" Comment).

Dawkins' theistic God died with Friedrich Nietzsche. God is no longer a noun. Uncertainty (which includes pain, suffering and death, along with all other so-called "imperfections") is now seen as part of the game, just as language contains redundancy in order to get the message across. In science, it is called quantum physics; you just don't know what is going to happen from second to second, just like life! Perfectionism (and all that sin stuff) went out with traditional Christianity. Both in quantum physics and in the new Christianity, relationship is all the rage.

Things only exist because of their relationship to each other; life only exists because of relationships between living creatures. Grenville GilbertOttery St Mary, Devon

Robin McKie deployed a well-worn argument against intelligent design: creation is flawed, therefore there can be no Creator. I would have thought the implicational relationship between such statements is hardly necessary and sufficient. Evangelical atheists need to learn from evangelical Leavers: unintelligent confusion does not work. The Rev David BlackTilston, Cheshire

A failsafe system for data

I applaud Evgeny Morozov for his, once again, insightful analysis of the challenge of regaining control of our data from the technology behemoths ( "There is a leftwing way to challenge big tech over our data. Here it is", Comment).

The combination of citizen control of data and appropriately regulated access by democratically accountable entities, where the use of data can make a real difference, be that by a council or city, is compelling. However, one challenge will be data portability. Is data retained or does it move with the individual? If it is retained, then data can continue to be exploited for the benefit of remaining citizens, but that comes with the gradual erosion of an individual's ability to control their data and understand how it is used. This conflict is not insurmountable, but must be overcome if the likes of Google, Facebook and Amazon aren't supplanted by the likes of London, Birmingham and Manchester. Neil MacehiterGreat Shelford, Cambridge

A bridge too far...

I think you are a little hard on the bridge designer Riccardo Morandi when comparing the disaster in Genoa with that of another of his bridges, at Lake Maracaibo in Venezuela in the 1960s ( "Amid the hunt for culprits, Genoa's tragedy points to a malaise at Italy's heart", Comment). The bridges are remarkably similar, but the circumstances totally different. It would be an amazing design that could withstand an oil tanker at speed, as happened at Maracaibo. Alan SugarmanWest Chiltington, West Sussex

Buying a better education?

I don't understand in what way William Miller thinks he supports state education while sending his children to fee-paying schools ( "?I'd worked so hard to get away from the scrutiny of my father...", Observer magazine). Perhaps he tells himself he is easing overcrowding or raising the bar. Wealthier parents buying better-resourced education for their children is so unfair as to be antisocial.

Dave Hayward Kenilworth, Warwickshire

Marxism today

Anne McElvoy, as a senior editor of the Economist, would, one assume, be clear headed and objective. Yet she finds difficulty checking the rush of blood to the head when trying to scan the world beyond the comfortable status quo ( "US Democrats are struggling to make sense of a socialist surge", Comment). Several emotional semantic slips destroy her attempts at objectivity. Instead of an increase in membership of the Labour party, she gives us "an insurgent grab". Instead of a "manifesto", she prefers to call it "siren songs" and the content is just "stuff" that she propagandises as "free", though they're fully costed. She also falsely assumes that Marxism failed, whereas Karl Marx never laid out a blueprint for government. E JonesEastington, Gloucestershire

A truly natural woman

I agree with Sean O'Hagan that Aretha Franklin's pain and heartbreak were transmuted into song ( "Aretha: heartbreak and hope, struggle and inspiration", Focus).

Her legacy will be a uniquely beautiful and expressive voice that moved everyone who heard it to tears and turned every song she sang, most of which were not written by her, into soul. And unlike Madonna, Aretha Franklin did not need gimmicks or continuously to reinvent herself. She made me feel like a natural human.

Stan Labovitch

Windsor

Brexiteers on prejudice

It's interesting that, according to the Opinium poll reported in last week's Observer ( Labour suspends ex-MP over antisemitism row, News), the percentage of the total number of voters believing the Labour party is prejudiced against British Jews is almost identical to the percentage of the total number of voters who wanted to leave the EU. Something the Labour leadership might reflect on the next time it considers repeating Jeremy Corbyn's "the British people have spoken... we must respect that result" line. David ClarkeBristol

Pooh at the Pole

Winnie the Pooh and co went on an Expotition, not "expertition" - in what were they experts ( Christopher Robin film review, New Review). Gill HallifaxLondon NW6

urn:contentItem:5YCK-3961-F0JC-M08K-00000-00LETTERS: Branching out for tree planting plan2020-03-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:32ZLexisNexisLETTERS: Branching out for tree planting planGazette Reporter

I READ with interest the letter from June Emerson (February 5) regarding tree planting plans in the Ryedale area.

I can advise that Ryedale Lions Club has recently joined a Lions District project whereby each club within district undertakes to plant 10 trees for each club member each year for the next five years.

For Ryedale Lions Club that equates to 1,500 trees and for district 60,000 trees.

We are in contact with Pickering Town Council to agree suitable locations for the planting of these trees.

This initiative offers Ryedale Lions Club an opportunity to invite members of our community to come along and join us in an activity which reflects one of the Lions core service areas. What better an introduction to Lions?

For further information please make contact via our website.

Frank Hayward, president of Ryedale Lions Club

Show your support

ACROSS Yorkshire and the Humber over 76,000 people are living with dementia and 850,000 are affected UK-wide.

Dementia is now the UK's biggest killer, with someone developing it every three minutes.

Alzheimer's Society has joined up with Department for Transport on their "it's everyone's journey" campaign, to address the fact that too many disabled people, including people with dementia, don't feel confident using public transport.

Two-thirds of people living with dementia in the UK, live in the community and less than half (47 per cent) of people living with dementia feel like they are a part of their community.

So we are calling on the travelling public to help beat the isolation and loneliness by learning more about some simple steps to support people with disabilities to travel:

l Please be considerate and aware of your fellow passengers - by offering help if someone looks lost or keeping the noise down if anyone looks visibly distressed to help anxieties.

l Please be patient and take your time - support people living with dementia and other conditions by allowing people some extra time, should they require it. This could be using ticket barriers, finding a seat or getting onto a bus.

l Please be prepared to give up the priority seat - dementia is one of many disabilities which is not visible, so please be aware of other passengers and be prepared to give up the priority seat to anyone who might need it.

l Please respect accessible toilet users - an accessible (disabled) toilet is not just a facility for wheelchair users. Please respect the fact that not all disabilities are visible and you may not always be aware of someone's accessibility needs.

Transport is at the heart of our lives and we all have the power to collectively create a more supportive travel environment for people living with dementia, and other conditions.

We owe it to the 850,000 people in the UK currently living with dementia to understand the condition better, so that they can live better.

To find out more go to everyonesjourney.campaign.gov.uk/

Angela Rippon, Alzheimer's Society Ambassador

Don't drag heels

I'M hugely encouraged by the landmark plans announced by the Government to give Ofcom powers to regulate social networks.

The safety of children online has been compromised for too long, but this breakthrough could pave the way in setting a global standard in protecting children.

The Government has shown a commitment to leading change by standing up to big tech firms. Now, Ministers must move swiftly to ensure that Ofcom is given the necessary powers, allowing it to enforce substantial fines to social networks not doing enough to prevent adults grooming children on their sites.

The internet is a wonderful place for young people to learn and social networks form a big part of their friendships, enabling them to seek support from peers. However, no longer should children be exposed to harmful content and abuse because of a slap-dash approach by tech giants.

It's why we've long called for, through our Wild West Web campaign, an independent regulator, safe accounts for children and detailed reporting on how tech firms are keeping children safe.

An estimated 90 online child sexual offences have taken place each day since the Government published the Online Harms White Paper last April. It's gone on too long and social networks must not be allowed to continue dragging their heels.

Helen Westerman, NSPCC, service head for local campaigns

Boys gave up day off to deliver goodwill FRIDAY was a special day on the calendar, Valentine's Day, with many people receiving flowers to mark the occasion.

As part of their charity section of the Duke of Edinburgh award, two enterprising 13-year-old pupils, Joey Fletcher and Owen Reynolds, from Kirk Hallam School, decided to deliver bouquets of flowers to eight Care Homes in West Hallam and Ilkeston.

Carrying the flowers and bedecked with balloons, the two caring young men walked, firstly round each care home in West Hallam, then continued on to Ilkeston - all of this on a day when school was closed.

They were welcomed at each home, delivered their flowers, spoke to the recipients and proved what a credit they are to their families and to their school. How refreshing, in this day and age, that they cared enough to forgo their day off and give pleasure to others; also raising money, by sponsorship, for suffers of dementia.

Special mention should also be given to Morrisons, Ilkeston, which provided the flowers that enabled the lads to carry out this wonderful endeavour.

The walk has so far raised a magnificent £450 for the Alzheimer's Society, as well as providing a well received visit to the recipients of these thoughtful gifts. Well done lads on a well thought out and caring task.

John Fletcher, West Hallam Threatened bus service is vital IT is my understanding that the Prime Minster has announced more money for bus services. Why is it then that our council, Derby City Council, has decided that it is no longer going to subsidise the 17A bus service ("Protest over cut to council's subsidy for city bus route", February 15)? Passengers have had no prior notice of this. We suddenly found out when a number of protesters, along with Councillor Martin Repton, were at the Darley Abbey stop.

The council's new budget for 2020/2021, approved the removal of the subsidy on February 12 and is due to be fully approved on February 26.

A council spokeswoman said "The 17A is the only remaining Derby City Council subsidised service. Derby City Council's contribution to the service is £9,000 per year. The service is only used by a small number of passengers and other direct services are available in Allestree and Darley Abbey. As yet there has been no formal notification of cancellation from the bus operator (Notts & Derby).

This service is also used as a "school bus" at the relevant times of the day. What about the kids ? The small number of people, are mainly older or infirm people, and it's a vital service for them. The service re-routes from the A6 around the Lambourn Drive estate, and on through the village of Darley Abbey before returning to the A6 via Broadway, into and out of the city.

Most of these people are unfit enough or unable to walk the distances in between to reach the A6, to catch other available routes. We need our bus. What next, the bus pass system? Lynda Sheppard, Derby Regulation of social media long overdue I AM hugely encouraged by the landmark plans announced by the Government to give Ofcom powers to regulate social networks.

The safety of children online has been compromised for too long, but this breakthrough could pave the way in setting a global standard in protecting children in their digital worlds.

The Government has shown a commitment to leading change by standing up to big tech firms. Now, ministers must move quickly to ensure that Ofcom is given the necessary powers, allowing it to enforce substantial fines to social networks not doing enough to prevent adults grooming children on their sites.

The internet is a wonderful place for young people to learn and social networks form a big part of their friendships, enabling them to seek support from peers.

However, no longer should children be exposed to harmful content and abuse because of a slap-dash approach by tech giants.

It's why we've long called for, through our Wild West Web campaign, an independent regulator, safe accounts for children and detailed reporting on how tech firms are keeping children safe.

An estimated 90 online child sexual offences have taken place each day since the Government published the Online Harms White Paper last April. It's gone on too long and social networks must not be allowed to continue dragging their heels.

Ally Sultana, NSPCC campaigns manager, Midlands We'll get used to HS2 benefits over time IT has recently been in the news regarding HS2 and protesters setting up camp.

People of mature years will be able to remember the roads in the British Isles without motorways.

All traffic had to use village roads and take a long time to commute.

I realise that there were not as many cars but surely, in this day and age, with technology, we are a lot better off, and in a few years time everyone will take things for granted.

A bit like the washing machine and central heating? V Thompson, Mickleover Stop foreign aid and save our care homes IT'S time this country of ours stopped giving out foreign aid and looked after its own people that have paid in to the system for years.

We now find in our area that seven care homes in Derbyshire are to close because they need to be refurbished and all these old people will have to be removed to other homes.

The Government must do something to save these homes under threat. We are a small island, this aid should be for us.

Mick Hotter, West Hallam

urn:contentItem:5VTX-WXN1-JCJY-G12N-00000-00Letters: play areas should be open to all;Planning applications that exclude affordable housing tenants from communal spaces should be rejected2019-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisOPINIONVersion:1Letters: play areas should be open to allPlanning applications that exclude affordable housing tenants from communal spaces should be rejected

As president of the Landscape Institute, I have been responding to our members discussing Rowan Moore's article on social segregation and play areas (" Dividing rich and poor is inevitable when developers run open spaces ", Comment). The case of Bayliss Old School and many other developments in London highlights inequality in access to play spaces, yet there is a wider inequality, where some children have limited access to any green space. According to the Greater London Authority, more than 20% of Greater London still lies in an area of deficiency in access to nature, which highlights the need for more accessible and higher quality green spaces.

The LI believes that good play spaces can give children and young people the freedom to play creatively together, allowing them to experience risk, challenge and excitement while reconnecting with nature. Play spaces should be a space in their own right, open to all and cross-generational. Planning applications that exclude affordable housing tenants from communal spaces should be rejected. We call on all local authorities and housing associations to ensure that play spaces are made accessible for all, regardless of tenure.

Our members can play a role in promoting quality green and play spaces for all in new developments and we need to take up this challenge as a profession and to communicate this to developers, local authorities and others in the sector. This will help us deliver our royal charter for the benefit of people, place and nature, for today and for future generations.

Adam White London WC1

In his commendable, necessary piece on social segregation in housing developments, Rowan Moore noted how developers are obliged to provide some affordable housing in any planning application. But this phrase - "affordable housing" - is generally left uninterrogated. It is rarely asked what affordable means. I have been variously informed that a household income of more than £60,000-£70,000 is needed to consider buying one of these houses. Given that the average wage is still below £30,000, this would be far from being generally "affordable" and even further from low cost or social housing. Whatever the price of these properties, it should be made clear, so that "affordable housing" is not used evasively. Gerard BellLondon SE17

Parliament, this is your time

Neal Ascherson's assertion that Brexit highlights the creeping of executive power is true (" Archaic, authoritarian, unequal to the challenge - parliament is broken ", Comment). The separation of powers, fundamental to the functioning of British democracy, has become blurred. Drawing the executive from within the legislature, composed according to an entrenched two-party political system, enables the government of the day to ram unscrupulous bills through parliament; Montesquieu would be screaming "Tyranny!" on College Green if he were alive today. Brexit breaks the mould. It loosens the grip of the elective dictatorship that typically strangles the Commons, halting the executive in its tracks, like a trespasser caught in a spotlight.

But Ascherson's claim that the "non-constitution" is archaic and hides the true position of authority is misplaced. Lesson 1 of any constitutional law module makes it clear that parliament is sovereign. Archaic? More like dynamic and flexible. The unwritten constitution enables the UK to adapt and rise to challenges presented by pressing circumstances; the gun control problems plaguing America provide evidence of the trappings of a constitution set in stone long ago. Parliamentary sovereignty and the constitution's adaptive ability have arguably never been more necessary than now.

Parliament should see Brexit as an opportunity to dust itself off and to answer the challenge demanded of it by halting the advancing influence of intrusive executive power. If the referendum result was fuelled by a desire to repatriate sovereignty, Brexit is merely the first hurdle at the start of an infinite track. Giordano Magnante London SE1

Pier pressure

Was Chris Grayling involved with the Hastings pier fiasco? asks your correspondent ("Prickly pier connection?" Letters ). No, but Amber Rudd was - and still is. Her infamous lack of judgment continues here with her backing the new owner, "Sheikh" Abid Gulzar, to the hilt (possibly because he's an influential Eastbourne Tory, with a picture of Margaret Thatcher on his office wall). Archie Lauchlan, director Re: A Pier, Hastings pier documentary Hastings, East Sussex

Poverty shames the UK

Study after study has shown that underachievement in schools is closely associated with poverty: poor housing, poor healthcare, inadequate diet, a decaying school environment and weak parenting skills (" Malign ideas driving child poverty haunt Brexit debate ", editorial). That one in three children lives below the poverty line in the UK today is shaming.

The UK is becoming a more unequal society by the day. Central to the far right's plans for a low-wage, low-tax, lightly regulated society after Brexit is to increase rapidly this inequality: greater inequity in housing, income, healthcare and education.

Tony Blair famously claimed his three priorities for office to be "education, education, education". He was right. Enlightened Victorian reformers knew it. Increasing inequity in state education engendered by cuts and marketisation policies is inflicting misery and disadvantage on generations of the poor for years to come, destroying opportunity and damaging society for all of us. Dr Robin C RichmondBromyard, Herefordshire

How to beat big tech

Could university students doing computer sciences, media and communication, journalism or similar provide the answer to Carole Cadwalladr's concern about the lack of resources or commitment to understanding how the tech companies are manipulating information (" Cambridge Analytica a year on: 'a lesson in institutional failure' ", New Review)? Projects by law students looking at miscarriages of justice have had success and have given the students valuable skills.

The knowledge gained by looking in depth at real issues would surely be invaluable to anyone wishing to pursue these areas as a career and could provide a level of information and support to people trying to work out how to manage this insidious problem. Gillian Paczynski Sunderland

Taking aim at objectives

In the continuing debate about whether there has been grade inflation in universities, there is a factor whose possible influence on the rise in the number of first-class honours seems to have been overlooked, namely the culture of "aims and objectives" ("Students still make the grade", Letters ).

When I was a student (1965-72), it was often difficult to find out about the syllabus one was supposed to study. A student could easily get the impression that everything in the area in question was to be studied. When I put this complaint to the Oxford philosopher Philippa Foot, I remember her giving me a stare and saying: "But one just goes to the shelves and reads."

By contrast, it is now the practice for every course to have a detailed set of aims and objectives. Faced with an essay or an exam script that does all but only these things, a marker may think she or he can't do other than give the highest possible mark. Yet such a script may well be short of the originality and imagination that used to form a significant part in the award of first-class honours. Paul BrownseyBearsden, Glasgow

Take it on the chin, Barbara

I was surprised to find that Barbara Ellen had resurrected physiognomy from the graveyard of pseudoscience (" Beards have to go out of fashion soon (with any luck) ", Comment). Perhaps she could specify which facial features, potentially concealed by beards, she thinks reveal men's "true (evil? disturbed?) natures"? No? I thought not, otherwise folk wouldn't be taken in by clean-shaven fraudsters, and psychiatric diagnosis would be so much easier. Never mind, I've got better things to do. Like trimming my beard. John GeeCapel Dewi, Aberystwyth

urn:contentItem:5T7T-WHX1-JD39-X2PB-00000-00LETTERS ROUND-UP: Lib Dem vision...Using tech to protect children2018-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:32ZLexisNexisLETTERS ROUND-UP: Lib Dem vision...Using tech to protect childrenReaders' letters

THE Liberal Democrats have launched our "York 2019" campaign; an exciting opportunity for local residents to share their views and ideas on how to improve the city.

With less than a year to go until the May 2019 elections in York, significant work is ongoing to create an ambitious plan for the city.

As part of "York 2019", the Liberal Democrats would like to know what residents want to see happen in York over the next five years; from big ideas that affect the entirety of the city, to specific suggestions on what could change in local communities.

As Liberal Democrats, it is important to us that our plan reflects the aspirations of residents and local communities across the city. That is why all submissions we receive during York 2019 will be considered as we set out our priorities for the upcoming elections.

For those who want to have their say, please share your thoughts via www.yorklibdems.org.uk/york2019, or email york2019@yorklibdems.org.uk, to get involved.

Stephen Fenton, Ward councillor for Dringhouses and Woodthorpe,

Askham Lane, York

Use tech to flag up the risks to children

LAST week the Home Secretary laid down a much-needed challenge to big tech companies at the NSPCC's HQ in London.

Sajid Javid said he was demanding change to protect children from online groomers as well as urging the industry to tackle the vile trade in indecent images.

And not before time. NSPCC research shows the equivalent of one child in every primary school classroom surveyed has been sent a naked or semi-naked image from an adult; and one in 50 had sent a nude or semi-nude image to an adult. That is appalling, but it isn't inevitable.

Social media sites often know where we shop and what we buy to target us with adverts. If they can use that technology for profit then why not to flag the risks to our children? It's time the Government acts and forces social networks to play their part.

The NSPCC's Wild West Web campaign is calling on Mr Javid and Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright to create an independent regulator, with the power to investigate and to fine social networks which fall short. And social networks must be forced to publish annual transparency reports about the scale of abuse on their platforms.

Of course, parents need to take steps to ensure their children are as safe as can be online, and we must teach children online safety in schools. But online platforms should be built to be safe in the first place, just like any other product used by children.

Helen Westerman

NSPCC Campaigns Manager for the North, Leeds

urn:contentItem:5WRS-7MV1-JBJ7-N07P-00000-00Letters: Taxing big tech on turnover is simple2019-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:32ZLexisNexisLetters: Taxing big tech on turnover is simple

Stamp duty, red tape, building industry crisis, executive pay, nuclear submarines, hydroponic farms.

More creative approach key to tax

Just like land taxes are a more sensible way to tax property than current stamp duty arrangements (??????Removing stamp duty a no-brainer'', Letters, August 5), the most sensible way to tax big tech is a turnover tax on Australian-generated revenues   (??????Taxing big tech a mistake,'' August 5).Both land taxes and turnover taxes are based on a dollar value. Taxes need to be designed to fit circumstances. In developed economies with concerns of growing inequality, it is sensible to have a mixture of taxes that apply to wealth, turnover and profits.The high-tech companies that may not yet be profitable have generated tremendous wealth to owners. They compete and devalue other companies that pay taxes on profits. Taxing turnover of high-tech companies is simply creating a level playing field.It is a not a difficult accounting exercise to estimate the profits generated by high-tech companies in Australia. Then applying appropriate benchmark taxes to turnover helps create a balanced tax regime.Keeping the "big picture" in mind is vital in designing tax systems. Turnover taxes are efficient and can be collected upfront with GST. Years of uncertainty and legal disputes based around a profits-based tax are avoided.

Graeme TroyWagstaffe, NSW

We deem pensioners, why not companies?

Richard Holden raises then ponders the legitimate question of taxing big tech (August 5).Professor he might be, but tax advisers could teach him a thing or three about the difference between accounting profit and tax profit.Unless the economics that I studied under professors Shape, Porter and Head has disappeared in the years since, multinationals invest rationally and only where the required rate of return can be earned.If we can deem pensioners to have earned interest, we can deem companies to have earned profits, even if that be by reference to their own internal required rate of return.

Chris WallisAlbert Park, Vic

Policy changes always in government's favour

As an ACT ratepayer and having closely watched in amazement ACT government revenue figures covering the 10 or more years since the ACT government announced a supposed budget ??????revenue neutral'' policy of removing stamp duty and replacing it with significant rates levy increases every year, I feel it appropriate to respond to Joanne Seve's letter ??????Removing stamp duty is a no-brainer''.The appropriate response is why shouldn't every other state and territory ratepayer be financially punished the way ACT ratepayers have been?It should always be remembered that a government never makes a policy change unless it benefits the government itself and its budget finances.Ratepayers are merely collateral donors who must be ??????buttered over'' as well as possible so they remain bamboozled by all the supposed intangible benefits they receive from the change.

Wayne GrantPhillip, ACT

Boards' self-regulation really self-deception

Australian Institute of Company Directors CEO Angus Armour says ??????Prescriptive rules for boards won't boost pay accountability'' (August 5) while being vague on what will.The alternative principles-based approach is malleable enough to be retro-fitted to any template. The instances of industry captains and their managerial stewards overpaying themselves while paying lip-service to shareholder value, customer satisfaction and community trust show that self-regulation is self-deception bordering on imagined reality. It survives only because self-interested groups believe so.If money-based carrot is thus a blunt tool, why not try the stick? Where documented damage has been done, let not chairs and CEOs and their conflicted advisers hide behind the corporate cloak to escape culpability, but serve custodial time. They might reflect during the resulting loss of liberty on what might have been for themselves and affected stakeholders, while being boarded and lodged at taxpayer expense. What could be fairer?

Ramani VenkatramaniRhodes, NSW

???Pacific' submarine fleet obvious answer

If the bond between the US and Australia is unbreakable, why not co-invest in a "Pacific" submarine fleet with offensive and defensive capabilities? It would seem to solve all the defence-related issues, it could be jointly manufactured, maintained and based in Adelaide, Perth and Darwin. It would just need Australians to grow up and recognise nuclear power is essential, not optional, when it comes to the environment, whether it be in terms of security or sustainability.

Martin JamesCrafers, SA

Hydroponic agriculture the best way forward

Qatar, a desert nation, now has a thriving dairy industry. Because of the blockade placed on Qatar by other countries in the Persian Gulf, it has had to look at other resources to feed its population. Since June 2017, Qatar has built major indoor farms and, in turn, has created a major dairy industry that is now exporting dairy products. It is also building solar-powered hydroponic indoor farms to grow fruit. If this can be done in Qatar's deserts, why can't it be done in Australia?Sundrop Farms in Port Augusta, South Australia, is leading the way in hydroponic produce production.With incentives from state and federal governments, Australia could create a massive hydroponic agriculture industry, thousands of jobs and cement its position as an international food bowl.

Malcolm WebsterBoronia, Vic

urn:contentItem:5VP9-BX91-JCG7-V0SB-00000-00Letters: The Growing Recycling Crisis2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisLetters: The Growing Recycling Crisis


Is This the End of Recycling?
Last year, China restricted imports of certain recyclables. For decades, the United States had sent the bulk of its recycling there; now, waste-management companies are telling towns, cities, and counties that the market for their recycling no longer exists. These municipalities can either pay much higher rates to get rid of their recycling, or throw it all away.


As the trash piles up, Alana Semuels wrote in early March, American cities are scrambling to figure out what to do with everything they had previously sent abroad:
"Americans are going to have to come to terms with a new reality: All those toothpaste tubes and shopping bags and water bottles that didn't exist 50 years ago need to go somewhere, and creating this much waste has a price we haven't had to pay so far."

There aren't sufficient financial incentives for manufacturers to design products or packaging so that it can be easily recycled. And without carbon taxes and taxes on mercury pollution, for example, waste-to-energy plants can likely win the economic competition. Cities and organizations have struggled for decades to advance recycling beyond about 35 percent of the waste volume-plastics being a pernicious problem because of the many types and the many products using several types. It is a big mess and needs more specific regulations, likely nationwide or globally. Portland, Oregon, remains a good example of a viable basic setup: have recycling be free to new city residents, who pay only landfill fees. But this doesn't solve much of the problem. Huge incentives need to exist for manufacturers to use recycled content in their products-e.g. 50 percent reduced corporate income or property taxes.
Christopher Juniper
Portland, Ore.

I truly believe that legislation must be passed requiring manufacturers to be responsible for recycling the packaging they use for their products.
Elizabeth Lobo
Tuscon, Ariz.

When and how are we to hold corporations accountable for their role in producing waste? Some big companies have promised to reduce packaging and reduce single-use plastic by 2025. We have to hold them to that. In the meantime, real pricing of products-which includes the cost of dealing with plastic waste-would certainly make consumers think twice about using so many things so mindlessly. All this requires strong civil-society action, and sustained public pressure on big businesses. They do respond to such pressure. Much research is already under way on alternatives. Governments could incentivize and fast-track this research.
Rohini Nilekani
Bangalore, Karnataka, India

Your piece "Is This the End of Recycling?" ignores one obvious solution to the rising costs of recycling: taxing people enough to pay for this essential service. Indeed, the word tax does not appear once anywhere in the piece.
Someone writing about the crisis in recycling should not characterize recycling as simply being too expensive, because this accepts the framing of the issue from the tax-avoidance perspective. Rather, the writer should report from a more neutral standpoint that acknowledges Americans' refusal to accept taxation on the level that is necessary to pay for important aspects of our civilization.
Americans' pathological resistance to taxes has real consequences. Yet your piece leaves this self-destructive ideology completely unexamined, despite the central role that it plays in the issue of recycling.
Ferdinand Cesarano
New York, N.Y.

Is this the end of recycling? Let's hope so. As the article by Ms. Semuels properly points out, recycling does not make economic sense for the companies that collect the recycled materials. It is often half the cost to bury the items that are collected for recycling. With just this data point, we can see that recycling does not add up. If you add the cost of the separate "streams" used to collect the stuff at the neighborhood level, and you add some value for the time misspent by households sorting their trash into three or four different bins, you do the math and see that it might make people feel good, but it is an inefficient use of resources.
Keith Ogden
Sausalito, Calif.

Aluminum and glass containers can be recycled back into themselves-a "closed loop"-and aluminum pays for itself to be recycled.
I was a national spokesperson for Alcoa's can-recycling activity for 12 years. The company spent about $100 million alone in promotional ads over that time and developed machinery, a national recycling network, and technology that was nonexistent when we started. We did this to protect the convenience package of the can, and so many good things happened as a result. If your story is true, I am greatly distressed.
John Van Devender
Brookfield, Conn.

Require producers of products to take back both their packaging and the used-up products. They can charge a deposit or not. In addition, the entire supply chain needs to operate in both directions. If you buy a product in a store, that store must take back the packaging and the dead products to return them to the middleman supplier or to the manufacturer. If you get a product delivered, you return the waste by shipping it back to the place you bought from. Yes, Amazon is going to have to take back all the used packaging and products they sell us, and return the waste to the original producers or suppliers.
It is true the producer still might not recycle-it might be cheaper for the producer to simply dump the waste in a landfill. But there would be every incentive for companies to learn how to make better use of their waste, and for other companies to offer services using waste as feedstock. Either way, the cost and burden of dealing with waste would now fall on the producers, not cities or consumers. That should give the waste producers a lot more incentive to be more careful in how they design packaging and products, as well as more inventive and innovative in finding new ways to use the waste stream.
Larry Lawton
Aberdeen, Wash.

"The best way to fix recycling is probably persuading people to buy less stuff ..." No. The best way to fix recycling is to reduce the world's population. The planet cannot support the current human population. There are too many people consuming too much of the planet's resources and discarding the accompanying packaging.
Allan Lovelace
Beaumont, Calif.

Thank you for bringing attention to the growing recycling crisis. In developed countries, trash- and waste-management systems are often out of sight and therefore out of mind. The reality is that what happens to our waste affects all of us long after we've disposed of it.
And it affects the ocean, too. An estimated 8 million metric tons of plastic enters the ocean every year, much of it coming from places around the world where people don't have the luxury of recycling facilities or curbside trash pickup. With nowhere else to go, trash floats down rivers, eventually reaching the sea. That's why alongside other measures to end plastic pollution, Ocean Conservancy has pushed to increase investment in waste collection and recycling. While we like to think of the U.S. as a model, the country is among the top 20 contributors to plastic flowing into our ocean. We can do better.
One action everyone can take today is reducing our reliance on single-use plastic. But the end goal is a circular economy where reusing materials is the preferred, cost-effective choice. Articles like this show that we have no time to lose.
Janis Searles Jones
CEO, Ocean Conservancy
Washington, D.C.
Alana Semuels replies:
I talked to a few people who advocated for a "circular economy," in which everything that is used is taken back and recycled. This may sound extreme, but there are certainly ways that big businesses or universities could get involved so that the economy is more circular, if not completely circular. Institutional purchasers such as universities or big tech companies could tell their suppliers that they won't buy products like computers or telephones unless the suppliers pledge to take the products back at the end of their useful life and recycle or repurpose them. But there's currently little incentive for them to do so.

urn:contentItem:5P74-FY01-JBM5-R27M-00000-00letters to the editor2017-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:32ZLexisNexisLOCALBPg. 8letters to the editorRoy Winter Mike McCracken Christy Orders Megan Ahn Bob Schmidt John E. Gahan Rob Jason James D. Lemon

Bridge nets would make traffic even worse

Regarding "We must try to prevent Coronado Bridge deaths" (Aug. 4): Coronado Mayor Richard P. Bailey recommends installing nets under the Coronado Bridge to reduce suicides. Bailey writes, "Typically, the people that end their lives by jumping do so without any hesitation." "Within minutes, the car is towed away and traffic continues to move like normal."

When a potential suicide jumper is intercepted by authorities, however, "Standard protocol requires the bridge to be closed in both directions, while trained specialists work to help the individual contemplating suicide." This creates a traffic nightmare.

Adding a net to catch people who jump from the bridge is a humane attempt to save lives. It will also create more traffic problems if "standard protocol" is followed each time a person jumps and is rescued from the net. What is the logic of closing the bridge in both directions? What are the objections to changing the protocol?

Roy Winter

Escondido

Pick one good name for the Coronado Bridge

I just need to vent about when the Bay Bridge is mentioned in the paper and also on TV. I want to know why is it seems to be called the Coronado Bay Bridge when something "bad" happens and it is the San Diego Bay Bridge when something "good" takes place, like a race or walk?

Back in 1969, at the opening of the bridge, it was referred to as "The San Diego-Coronado Bay Bridge." It just seems like through the years, it has become easy to take shortcuts when mentioning the bridge. It just seems that these shortcuts create a image of good and bad.

This image happens a lot throughout the media. I just would like it to be consistent. Maybe we can call it San Diego Coronado Bay Bridge or SDC Bridge for short.

Mike McCracken

Coronado

Don't glorify those who mooch off of society

I am a summer visitor, and as great as your weather is, each year I still find things about California that are absurd. Per your "Street Art" series, I understand that it's nice to recognize the plight of the homeless, to see them as individuals, etc.

But what has the city come to when it openly celebrates a man ("Bernardo G," July 30) who was busted and jailed for drug smuggling, crossed the border illegally again, and now plans to mooch off our social services system and then someday "maybe get a job"?

Are we supposed to be happy about this guy loitering around Balboa Park? Glad he sneaked back in? Happy to share our tax dollars with him? I doubt I am alone in finding this outrageous. The man doesn't belong here. Perhaps Steve Breen should go to Mexico and see how well he would be treated if he behaved like Bernardo.

Christy Orders

Coronado

Gallegos should just mosey out of town now

Regarding "Embattled SANDAG leader to step down by year-end" (Aug. 9): Thank you for sharing San Diego Association of Governments Executive Director Gary Gallegos' quote - "I want to go be a cowboy and ride my tractor and chase a few cows and watch alfalfa grow and let somebody else worry about our future."

Our community should be outraged that the board voted unanimously on Friday to "re-evaluate" Gallegos' employment contract instead of voting to end his employment contract.

Megan Ahn

San Diego

Does Google now have an unfair advantage?

Eleven of the U-T economists this past Sunday ("Econometer," Aug. 6) showed their faith in market forces such as new competition, new technology, etc., keeping a rein on the market power of the big tech companies.

That may be true in the long run, but many big companies (Standard Oil, railroads, U.S. Steel, big pharma, Microsoft, Google) have used their market clout to rack up dubious profits for extended periods.

Google, for example, just got hit with a $2.7 billion fine from European antitrust courts. Sometimes free markets need rules/regulations to balance the market leverage the big guys have over weaker buyers and/or weaker competitors. Google makes most of its money from advertising. Be interesting to ask the U-T economists if they think the playing field is level between Google and, say, old-line media such as newspapers.

Bob Schmidt

La Jolla

Give diplomacy a chance in North Korea

The shouting match between President Donald Trump and North Korean President Kim Jong Un has now reached the point where North Korea has threatened to attack Guam and the United States has threatened to unleash "fire and fury" on North Korea.

It is time for both sides to take a deep breath. If fire and fury is actually unleashed on North Korea, it will in turn destroy the city of Seoul, South Korea, and several hundred thousand people living there, including U.S. military personnel. That is a given.

It is my impression that Kim Jong Un primarily wants to be recognized, and praised as a great leader, no matter how unjustified. Other world leaders have wanted the same, so why not just give it to him?

Put up a banner saying that he is a "Prince among Men." It will cost nothing and might just reduce the tension.

John E. Gahan

San Diego

Nation should step up missile defense options

With the inevitable proliferation of adversaries gaining intercontinental ballistic missile capabilities (like the unstable North Korean leader ), not to mention China and Russia, which already have stout ability, can this country please place hundreds or even thousands of Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) systems throughout our nation and around the world?

Current estimates say the THAAD system is 60 percent successful and the 30 to 40 we have cost about $10 billion per year. Simple math, if we increased this unique technology to $50 billion per year, we would have a hundreds in place within 10 years.

With a defense budget of almost $600 billion, surely this defensive system needs to be expanded exponentially, and would be a more vital defense asset than another ship or a few planes or a dozen tanks, without increasing the budget. Let's get ahead of a problem for a change instead of being behind the curve

Rob Jason

Mission Valley

Trump, Padres must go back to drawing board

I honestly believe that President Trump thinks he is making the right moves.

Then again, so do the Padres. Results?

James D. Lemon

San Diego

urn:contentItem:5FCF-P5V1-JC8F-22FP-00000-00Letters To The Editor2015-02-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisAPg. 9Letters To The EditorLettersLancaster, PA

Muslim teacher tells it like it is

Thank you to LNP reporter Earle Cornelius for his coverage of Muslim teacher Walead Mohammed Mosaad, and his presentation "What the Prophet Came to Teach Us," Feb. 13 at the Islamic Community Center of Lancaster ("ISIS and the Muslim disconnect," Faith & Values, Feb. 14).

In it was the reminder, often lost sight of, that Islamic State - more aptly referred to by Muslims as Daesh - does not represent most Muslims. Mosaad goes on to say that its use of the Quran to justify their killing is taking the texts out of context and the meaning of the verses. "They fit the verse to their agendas," he is quoted as saying.

What a good reminder to each of us - whether we are Christian (as I am), Jewish or Muslim as we try to follow God's word to each of us - to read the Scriptures without bending them to fit our own agendas.

It was also interesting to note that "a number of British imams suggested calling Islamic State the 'Un-Islamic State,' arguing that it is 'neither Islamic nor is it a state.'"

Priscilla Weidman

Lititz

Food Guy misses mark on GMOs

The article by Michael Long, The Food Guy defending GMO-containing food products "Standing up for genetically modified foods, Feb. 11) is a front for the producers of genetically modified organisms.

He is "baffled" that 57 percent of his readers believe that "GMO foods are not safe to eat." He goes on to accuse the supporters of the "GMO-free" labeling movement of hypocrisy, claiming they want to make money. What about the GMO producers? Are they not doing this just for the glory?

For millennia people hybridized plants and animals by cross-breeding similar species, resulting in the variety of food sources we know today. GMOs are made by introducing genetic material from an unrelated organism into a host organism. So, for example, Monsanto used a bacterial source to modify corn and soybeans to make them resistant to its Roundup herbicide. Quantitatively the resulting grains may have caloric and other measurable features equivalent to non-GMO grains, but the long-term effect on consumers is not known. The FDA approves GMO produce based on "independent" scientific studies funded by the producers. Are such tests to be trusted?

Because of this, many countries have banned GMOs. Industrialized agriculture in the U.S. has also found that cattle and poultry fed GMO corn are negatively affected. Plenty of studies indicate that consuming GMO-containing foods also affects human health.

Long concludes his promotional article by declaring that: "No doomsayer with a megaphone, or profit-taker with a 'GMO-free' label, will stop humankind from working toward the betterment of our species." Nonsense! GMOs will give Monsanto and others a global monopoly on food production; that is all. What the future will bring, no one knows.

Charles B. Lane

Lancaster Township

Big Ag 'progress' not good for people

This letter is written in response to "Standing up for genetically modified foods" (Food, Feb. 11).

First, the comparison of genetic engineering and the evolution of dogs: a key phrase here is "thousands of years," and only canine genes are bred into the new generation of dog - not genes from an entirely different species.

Second, and more importantly, the "betterment of our species'' is a hugely subjective statement. Are we really better as a species than we were 100 years ago, 1,000 years ago? We've managed to drastically increase our lifespans, but has our quality of life increased accordingly?

I would argue that as humans have progressed through time, we are actually worse off as a species, and the Earth has suffered for it. Our ravenous appetite for new technology and monopolistic business has turned what was not long ago a world of robust and vibrant communities into a single, homogenous (and dependent) mass.

The beautiful diversity of individual communities is evaporating away into that ominous cloud of 4G and Wi-Fi. Local and regional knowledge enables communities to benefit others through their differences, and also gives them strength to be independent, ensuring sustainability over generations.

The focus, I believe, should be on helping (and allowing) individual communities to thrive. There is nothing healthier than a diet of fresh, local, raw foods. Native vegetables, fruits and livestock are already well adapted to their specific regions. It is simply unnecessary to splice bacteria genes into corn so that we can grow it anywhere and everywhere while sickening the soil, pollinators, and ourselves with poisons. This wasteful, and ultimately dangerous, scenario applies to modifying the genomes of soybeans, cotton, alfalfa, and sugar beets as well. All to bandage a wound that won't heal until we shift our thinking from big business, big tech, and big profits - toward sustainable, community-based agriculture.

Genetic engineering is anything but a "natural progression.'' It is a forced result that has no place in nature or our bodies.

Lynn Malinak

Conoy Township

GMO apples not worth price

"GMO apples (have been) approved for development" by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, according to a Feb. 19 article in LNP. These apple varieties have been genetically engineered to resist turning brown after being sliced. Are you kidding me?

Does the USDA deem this trait in apples important enough to set loose these GMO genes in our orchards? This will almost assuredly lead to GMO contamination in the standard apple varieties. Do we really need non-browning apples? Are we that simple?

Can it be good for mankind if the world's food supply is controlled by a few GMO mega-corporations? Contrary to the mantra of the pro-GMO crowd, which says their goal is to feed the world, it seems to me (without having to dig too deep) that the real goal is feeding their pockets.

Steve Prescott

Conoy Township

Senate should confirm Quigley

Gov. Tom Wolf's nomination of John Quigley as secretary of the Department of Environmental Protection is under attack from state Senate Republicans and their paymasters in the oil and gas industry who are threatened by Quigley's approach of aggressively regulating drilling and pipeline activity in Pennsylvania.

Quigley is a highly qualified environmental policy expert who, while heading the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, wrote the moratorium on drilling in state parks and forests that the Corbett administration tried to overturn. Quigley has made clear that, while the federal government, not the state, decides where pipelines are sited, the state can actively regulate and monitor operations to control for noise, emissions, erosion, habitat disruption and the like.

Our state senators would do Pennsylvania and its environment a terrible disservice if they allow the drillers to block a consummate public servant such as John Quigley from serving this commonwealth.

Roger Cohen

Lancaster

urn:contentItem:5XY5-Y531-JBCN-42K8-00000-00Letters to the Editor: A driverless world2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisOPINIONLetters to the Editor: A driverless worldSan Francisco Chronicle

In the 1980s, Madonna sang about living in a material world in her song "Material Girl." However, now that Waymo has announced that its autonomous vehicles have logged 20 million miles in the past decade (Number of the Day, Business, Jan. 8), with 10 million of those miles coming in just the past year, I wondered: Might Madonna remake that "Material Girl" song for the 2020s, call it "Mechanical (or Robotic) Girl," and sing about living in a driver-less world?

Michelle Wang, Mountain View

Good decision, Pelosi

I am a long-standing resident of San Francisco and a long-standing registered Democrat. I write to strongly applaud, as do many others, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's decision to delay the delivery to the Senate of the articles of impeachment, at least until there is a reasonable prospect of some semblance of a fair trial in the Senate.

Indeed, the most recent announcement by John Bolton, that he would testify in a Senate trial if subpoenaed, already provides a modicum of validation of her decision.

As a concomitant matter, as seems widely acknowledged, a Sen. Mitch McConnell-driven summary trial in the Senate, a likely sham occurring before the State of the Union address, would enable the president to distort the State of the Union address into a megaphone through which to scream "Complete Exoneration."

Barry Sacks, San Francisco

Patterns of ecology

Regarding "Leave the leaves" (Letters, Jan. 8): Thank you to the letter writer encouraging the use of leaves to continue the normal life cycle of so many creatures instead of using blowers to "clean up the yard" and place all that wonderful detritus into the green bin.

The irony is these homeowners then go out and buy fertilizer or compost and put it right back into their garden when they could have used the leaves. Going green not only means driving electric cars and carrying reusable bags but understanding the more natural patterns of ecology.

Margaret Flaherty, Berkeley

Honor civil rights activism

Regarding "Schoolkids boost Ruby Bridges Day" (Jan. 8): I'm glad to read that civil rights activism is alive and well in this news story about a student campaign to get California to honor the first African American child to desegregate the all-white William Frantz Elementary School in Louisiana during the New Orleans school desegregation crisis in 1960. In Alameda, a school was named in honor of Ruby Bridges in 2006.

Might I suggest that those who want to further honor her include the 1964 painting "The Problem We All Live With" by Norman Rockwell in their campaign, so that others can visualize the significance of what Bridges did?

Eleanor Fischbein, Alameda

Surrounded by AI

Concerning "Big tech firms going to CES" (Daily Briefing, Jan. 4): According to this news item, cars now feature digital-assistant technology with Alexa built in, and there are more home appliances and gadgets that work with Apple's digital assistant, Siri.

I suppose it was bound to happen: In 2020, from our homes to our vehicles to the White House, artificial intelligence can be found almost everywhere.

Vivian Wexford, San Francisco

Pipeline problems

This president's efforts to reinstate the destructive Keystone XL Pipeline, at a time when the habitability of our planet hinges on our successes in arresting climate change, underscores his contempt for our environment and loyalty to the energy cartels. Unless climate changes can be arrested, conditions will worsen at accelerating rates as carbon dioxide concentrations become self perpetuating and approach the tipping point.

This can only result in widespread hunger and related wars. Nonetheless, he discredits the international scientific community and denies the existence of global warming and the need for reform measures. Reinstatement of this pipeline would discourage clean energy development while carrying toxic tar sand oil over fragile aquifers.

He has eliminated many environmental reform measures, which took years to implement — or has rendered them ineffective. A capricious child, he pursues his contemptuous policies, which cause environmental damage that cannot be measured.

Prime blame for the environmental damage from his dreadful actions lies not with President Trump, nor with Congress who defaulted their duties by permitting such governing. Instead it lies with the voters who planted such an unfit person in office, and then tolerate his destructive policies.

Robert Settgast, San Rafael

Genius of Trump economy

One problem with penalizing the wealthy for using already taxed income to invest in creating new products and services is that it stops growth. According to Sens. Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, the distribution of assets is a zero-sum game, and income increases for lower-income people must, by necessity, be taken from the billionaires.

This will kill innovation. Our economy has grown because of new ideas and new products, generally funded by seeking investments or borrowing from people who have already created their wealth. The history of our economy is one of innovation and growth. Most of the products that have made our lives better over time, like cars and computers, have also made people wealthier.

They have also been improved over time and become cheaper for people to buy. The difference in approach is that the Democrats believe the pie that must be split is static and that in order for one person to gain, someone else must lose.

The Republicans believe in growing the economy and making the pie bigger, so more is available for everyone. This is the genius of the Trump economy, fueled by tax cuts and regulatory reform.

Peter Behr, Richmond

urn:contentItem:5VBH-3NM1-JC3H-01VB-00000-00LETTERS TO THE EDITOR;Driverless cars could2019-02-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:31ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. A11LETTERS TO THE EDITORDriverless cars could

bring unemployment

I wonder if we as a nation are capable of learning from the past.

While politicians in our nation's capital play tit-for-tat over just about everything, there are important issues that need to be addressed.

An issue that is of particular concern to me is what technological advances are likely to do to the employment picture in the United States.

We know one of the main contributors to the despair and hopelessness that fueled the opioid crisis was lack of employment in traditionally blue collar jobs - these jobs went "overseas" or were just eliminated due in part to trade agreements and environment regulations (such as closing of the coal mines).

The next big tech breakthrough appears to be "driverless cars" or "automated vehicles."

Millions and millions of Americans, mostly blue collar workers, drive for a living - truck drivers, taxi and Uber drivers, parts deliveries, UPS and Fed Ex and other overnight services, etc.

I wonder if anyone in our government, or in private industry, has given any thought to what could be a tsunami of unemployment and its attendant hopelessness and despair.

Is anyone finding ways to mitigate the damage to these workers and their families? Is anyone discussing ways to encourage transition to different kinds of work?

We gain self-esteem from work and accomplishment, from feeling needed. When the jobs go away and unemployment is rampant, despair sets in. The unspoken message is: "We don't need you, you have nothing to contribute."

Although this technology is still in its developmental stage, I believe we need to start a conversation about this issue - because it's coming whether we like it or not.

Please encourage your elected representatives at the state and federal level to work with private enterprise to address this issue.

Carol Frazier is a resident of Ocean Pines

Energy efficiency cost-effective way to our needs

Re: Letters to the editor by Dan Ervin titled "Maryland could take lead on energy front" on Dec. 27, 2018, and "Wind, solar energy can destroy our quality of life" on April 24, 2018.

I am writing in reference to two letters written by Dan Ervin, a professor of finance with the Perdue School of Business at Salisbury University.

Mr. Ervin is a proponent of fracking and makes assertions that I believe are factually incorrect, misleading or otherwise objectionable.

In his letters, Mr. Ervin states EPA and independent environmental studies say "the production of natural gas is being done safely," but the EPA report he referred to had changes made to the executive summary just before public release by unnamed executive management.

The change deleted the previous claim of no "widespread systemic impacts." The body of the report states otherwise, documenting hundreds of drinking water contamination incidents. The EPA's scientific advisory board (26 out of 30) sharply criticized the executive summary. The four who did not all had oil and gas industry ties.

I know of no independent studies indicating fracking is safe.

In the December letter, Mr. Ervin states "Advanced drilling technology, safety standards and regulations are in place to protect the environment, landowners and rig workers." But industry would reject operating under those conditions because the cost and regulations of that sort would require more tax dollars to properly enforce than would be generated by taxes collected from industry.

Renewables are often criticized because they don't make enough money. Every month or two an article appears stating that no wind or photovoltaic project would succeed without government subsidies.

One of the functions of government is to promote new technology via subsidies. For example, the airline industry received about $150 billion in subsidies from 1918 to 1998. In 2011, Amtrak received about $1.4 billion. From 1950 to 2010, energy received about $838 billion in government subsidies.

Mr. Ervin states: "Maryland can't afford to ignore the other side of the energy equation. It would help, for example, if improvements were made in demand management to eliminate wasteful energy habits."

I completely agree with this comment but would strengthen it to say that energy efficiency should dominate our strategy versus increasing supply. Becoming more energy efficient is the fastest and most cost-effective way to reduce our energy needs.

Focusing on energy efficiency supports a high quality of life, economic improvement and job creation, while significantly addressing climate issues. The most cost-effective way to address energy needs is to reduce the load to the extent practical first, then address the energy gap with the energy needed by using renewables.

Fracking provides no benefit to the common good in our country or anywhere else. Most of Europe has banned fracking because it is such an inappropriate way to address energy needs.

Maryland is a great example of what can take place when both sides of the aisle work together on a fact-based, reasoned approach. We should be trying to export this concept to the federal level.

Jim Guy is a resident of Oldtown, Maryland

In the next shutdown,

begin with Congress

Did you know that 535 people in Congress each make $174,000 yearly.

They also get benefits such as retirement and Social Security, a $900,000 grant for salaries for 18 office employees, free flights, free airport parking and participate in Obamacare.

In the federal government shutdown that just ended temporarily, Congress got paid while 800,000 people were not paid.

The government is a three-legged stool - Executive, Judiciary and Legislative.

Congress, the legislative branch, is broken. They are supposed to work for us.

If there is another government shutdown, let it begin with Congress. Let the 800,000 people continue to work but shut Congress down first.

Eddie Johnson is a resident of Westover, Somerset County
